Theannabel Mercado
Editor/bookworm/writer from the Philippines. Books, food, coffee, cute stuff, and rock/heavy metal= ‚ù§Ô∏èÔ∏è
Apr 8

A writing lesson‚Ä¶ from a¬†bassist

I will be referring to creative writing and songwriting and creating art in general from time to time. Because writing (non)fiction and writing songs are both art, right?

Let me start with: I could not get enough of the first time I met my favorite local metal band Slapshock in person. Or at least three-fifths of them.

Thanks to a Facebook contest in celebration of the band‚Äôs twentieth anniversary* where fans would post their stories on the band‚Äôs impact on their lives, I was chosen to be part of the advance listening party of their upcoming album, Atake.**

Aside from that event being my first time to see the band (though unfortunately the vocalist and one guitarist were out of the country at the time) face to face, it was my first time to really chat with a member of a popular band.

I realized I shouldn‚Äôt have straight-up drunk that can of beer passed on to me at the event, since there were a good number of stuff that Lee‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe bassist‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand I have talked about, which were mostly about or somehow related to Slapshock‚Äôs music. Now I couldn‚Äôt recount what they exactly were. But I remembered well one thing he said‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand a very important one, whether you‚Äôre a musician or writer or both:***

Never underestimate your audience.

Even if you say you write only for yourself‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämusicians are authors, too, and vice versa, though in a different way‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthinking about your readers/listeners, your audience, is inevitable. When you post a blog entry, a short story, or an article like this online, or self-publish a book; or write and record songs and upload them either on Soundcloud or YouTube, release the whole bunch them as an indie album, or perform them live; you can‚Äôt help but ask yourself, ‚ÄúHow would my audience find this? Would they be happy? Would they enjoy it? Would this be significant to them just as it is to me?‚Äù

Now the question is, how does something, let‚Äôs say a work of art like a song or a literary piece, become significant? When it touches you in a certain way. Maybe you or a person you know have experienced in real life the story of the song or the literary piece. Or maybe you had an epiphany or two while reading or listening to it, as if God himself had spoken to you through that work of art.

The problem‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI remember Lee saying‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääis that the mainstream music industry thinks the general audience can only take in so much. Thinking about it, he was actually right. Have you ever wondered why most of the stuff we hear on the radio or some online music streaming app talk about romance (aka ‚Äúlove‚Äù in layman‚Äôs terms)? And with books, most are also about romance. No, I‚Äôm not bashing love songs and romance novels (romance is present in every song/poem/story/book of any genre anyway). What I am saying is, is that all we could talk about? Is that all we could share to other people as writers, as artists? Yes, we should also consider the wants and needs of our target audiences. But do we limit ourselves to what they know and can relate to‚Äîrather, what we think they know and can relate to?

What does the audience really want and need? How much can they really take?

How do we know the answers to those questions if we don‚Äôt try to share with them stuff they aren‚Äôt usually given? What about trying to talk to them, through our works of art, about other things in life than, well, romance? What about we explore these things ourselves, so we could better communicate these to other people? Darkness, sadness, death, destruction? Politics, religion, discrimination, crime, war? How the experience with those things feel like. And how we could overcome them. And also faith, hope, joy, peace, victory, truth, love‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe latter too great a concept to be boxed in just ‚Äúromance‚Äù. Where we can find them, and how we can practice them in such chaotic times in such a broken world.

Sometimes it‚Äôs not the audience limiting us creatives‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs us who limit them. How about we try to help them broaden their perspectives by creating for them art that gives them not only what they really want but also what they really need, art that helps them understand not only themselves but also other people around them, art that does not merely provide temporary escape from the harsh reality that is life but empowers people to face life head-on? And in so doing, our perspective as artists widens, too.

Never underestimate your audience.

That was one liberating piece of advice, not only for us writers (and other artists) but also for the audience whose lives we would get to touch.

And for that, I can never thank Lee‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the rest of Slapshock‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääenough.

*which fell on Valentine‚Äôs Day
**Filipino/Tagalog word for ‚Äúattack‚Äù
***Not verbatim, since we were talking in mixed Filipino and English (Taglish we call it), but that‚Äôs the exact thought.

P.S.: I have written about the listening party in a blog under my real (nick)name.
